verses.text: Then Deborah and Barak the son of Abinoam sang on that day, saying:
verses.comment: This is the introduction to Deborah's song. Reference to the pattern of victory songs as in Exodus 15:1.

verses.text: "Because the leaders took the lead in Israel, because the people offered themselves willingly, bless Yahweh!"
verses.comment: The name 'Yahweh' is used as in the original Hebrew.

verses.text: "Hear, O kings; give ear, O princes; I, even I, will sing to Yahweh; I will sing praise to Yahweh, the God of Israel."
verses.comment: Deborah addresses rulers, highlighting the act of public praise.

verses.text: "Yahweh, when you went out from Seir, when you marched from the field of Edom, the earth trembled, and the heavens dropped, yes, the clouds dropped water."
verses.comment: Recalls God’s power displayed at Sinai (cf. Ps. 68).

verses.text: "The mountains quaked before Yahweh, even Sinai before Yahweh, the God of Israel."
verses.comment: A reference back to the events at Sinai. 'Quaked' maintains meaning over 'melted'.

verses.text: "In the days of Shamgar the son of Anath, in the days of Jael, the highways were deserted, and travelers walked by roundabout ways."
verses.comment: Describes the unsafe conditions before Deborah's deliverance.

verses.text: "Village life ceased; it ceased in Israel, until I, Deborah, arose, I arose as a mother in Israel."
verses.comment: 'Village life' renders the Hebrew for thoroughfares/daily life.

verses.text: "They chose new gods; then war was in the gates. Not a shield or spear was seen among forty thousand in Israel."
verses.comment: Describes the idolatry and helplessness in Israel before the victory.

verses.text: "My heart is with the leaders of Israel, those who offered themselves willingly among the people. Bless Yahweh!"
verses.comment: Repetition for emphasis; personal address from Deborah.

verses.text: "Speak, you who ride on white donkeys, you who sit on rich carpets, and you who walk on the road."
verses.comment: Depicts the nobles, wealthy, and common travelers.

verses.text: "Far from the noise of archers at the watering places, there they will recount the righteous acts of Yahweh, the righteous deeds of his villagers in Israel. Then the people of Yahweh went down to the gates."
verses.comment: Reflects celebrations after victory.

verses.text: "Awake, awake, Deborah! Awake, awake, sing a song! Arise, Barak, and lead away your captives, son of Abinoam."
verses.comment: Victory is personified as awakening and leading captives.

verses.text: "Then down marched the remnant of the noble; the people of Yahweh marched down for me against the mighty."
verses.comment: 'The remnant of the noble' translates those who survived.

verses.text: "From Ephraim their root they marched down into the valley, after you, Benjamin, with your kinsmen. From Machir marched down commanders, and from Zebulun those who bear the staff of office."
verses.comment: Machir identifies with the tribe of Manasseh (cf. Num. 32:39).

verses.text: "The princes of Issachar were with Deborah; Issachar was faithful to Barak; into the valley they rushed at his heels. Among the divisions of Reuben there were great searches of heart."
verses.comment: 'Searches of heart' means internal debates or hesitation.

verses.text: "Why did you sit among the sheepfolds, to hear the piping for the flocks? Among the divisions of Reuben there were great searchings of heart."
verses.comment: Reuben is criticized for inaction.

verses.text: "Gilead stayed beyond the Jordan; and Dan, why did he stay with the ships? Asher sat still at the coast of the sea, staying by his landings."
verses.comment: Lists tribes who did not join in the battle.

verses.text: "Zebulun was a people who risked their lives to the point of death; Naphtali also, on the heights of the field."
verses.comment: Acknowledges the bravery of Zebulun and Naphtali.

verses.text: "The kings came, they fought; then fought the kings of Canaan, at Taanach by the waters of Megiddo; they took no gain of silver."
verses.comment: No plunder was gained by Israel's enemies.

verses.text: "From heaven the stars fought, from their courses they fought against Sisera."
verses.comment: Poetic of God’s intervention through nature.

verses.text: "The river Kishon swept them away, that ancient river, the river Kishon. March on, my soul, with strength!"
verses.comment: Kishon River was the site of Sisera’s defeat.

verses.text: "Then the horse’s hoofs beat, by the galloping, the galloping of his mighty ones."
verses.comment: The enemy’s cavalry is thrown into chaos.

verses.text: "Curse Meroz,’ says the angel of Yahweh, ‘curse its inhabitants thoroughly, because they did not come to the help of Yahweh, to the help of Yahweh against the mighty.’"
verses.comment: Meroz is an unknown town—a warning against neutrality in God’s battles.

verses.text: "Most blessed of women be Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite; of tent-dwelling women most blessed."
verses.comment: Echoes the language used for Mary in Luke 1:28.

verses.text: "He asked water and she gave him milk; she brought him curds in a lordly bowl."
verses.comment: The method of Jael’s hospitality is highlighted.

verses.text: "She put her hand to the tent peg and her right hand to the worker's hammer; she struck Sisera, she crushed his head; she shattered and pierced his temple."
verses.comment: Graphic description of Sisera’s death for poetic impact.

verses.text: "At her feet he sank, he fell, he lay still; at her feet he sank, he fell; where he sank, there he fell—dead."
verses.comment: The repetition emphasizes Sisera’s complete defeat.

verses.text: "From the window she looked out, Sisera's mother cried out through the lattice: 'Why is his chariot so long in coming? Why do the hoofbeats of his chariots delay?'"
verses.comment: The lament of Sisera’s mother.

verses.text: "Her wisest ladies answered her, yes, she herself returns answer to herself,"
verses.comment: Narrator’s aside about Sisera’s mother comforting herself.

verses.text: "'Are they not finding and dividing the spoil? A girl, two girls for each man; spoil of dyed garments for Sisera, spoil of dyed garments embroidered, two pieces of dyed work for the neck as spoil?'"
verses.comment: 'A girl, two girls' is literal, not euphemistic, as the Hebrew says 'a womb or two wombs.'

verses.text: "So may all your enemies perish, O Yahweh! But let those who love him be like the sun when it rises in its strength." And the land had rest for forty years.
verses.comment: Song’s conclusion and formulaic statement of peace (cf. Judg. 3:11).
